ayahs.text:
This opening verse declares that the Quran was revealed during Laylat al-Qadr, the Night of Power or Decree. The word 'Qadr' carries dual meanings: it signifies both honor and status, as well as destiny and decree, indicating that this night is unparalleled in its nobility and is decisive in determining destinies for the coming year.

The revelation of the Quran on this night can be understood in two ways: either the entire Quran was transferred from the Preserved Tablet to the angels responsible for revelation, who then delivered it gradually over 23 years, or this night marked the beginning of the Quranic revelation. This night is also referred to as the 'Blessed Night' in Surah Ad-Dukhan, emphasizing its sacred nature and spiritual significance.

The timing of this night is within the last ten odd nights of Ramadan, with many believing it to be the 27th night. However, due to differences in lunar calendar calculations across regions, it is recommended to seek this night throughout all the last ten nights of Ramadan to ensure its proper observance and the receiving of its tremendous blessings.

This verse poses a rhetorical question asking what could make one know the true significance and magnitude of Laylat al-Qadr. The question format emphasizes that the importance of this night is beyond ordinary human comprehension and requires divine explanation to be properly understood.

The rhetorical nature of this question serves to build anticipation and highlight the extraordinary nature of this night. It suggests that the significance of Laylat al-Qadr transcends normal human experience and understanding, requiring divine revelation to grasp its true meaning and value.

This questioning style is commonly used in the Quran to draw attention to matters of supreme importance, indicating that what follows will reveal something truly remarkable about this blessed night that would be impossible to comprehend without divine guidance.

The verse declares that Laylat al-Qadr is better than a thousand months, emphasizing its extraordinary spiritual value and the immense reward associated with worship during this night. This superiority applies to the good deeds performed on this night, which are more valuable than good deeds performed over a thousand months that do not include Laylat al-Qadr.

The number 'thousand' in Arabic culture represents an extremely large quantity, indicating that the blessings and rewards of this single night are virtually immeasurable. The superiority of this night can be understood in multiple ways: the spiritual benefit gained from worship equals that of over 83 years of regular worship, or the amount of divine mercy and blessings distributed on this night exceeds what is typically distributed over such an extended period.

This extraordinary value also relates to the historical significance of the Quran's revelation, as the good accomplished for humanity's guidance and reformation through the Quran's revelation in this one night surpassed any good achieved in any comparable extended period in human history. The tradition mentions that whoever stands in prayer during this night with faith and seeking reward from Allah will have all their previous sins forgiven.

This verse describes the descent of angels and the Spirit (referring to Angel Jibril) by their Lord's permission for every matter or decree. Angel Jibril is mentioned separately from other angels due to his special status as the leader of angels and his distinguished position near Allah, being described in Surah At-Takwir as mighty, having a firm place with the Owner of the Throne, obeyed there and trustworthy.

The special descent of angels and Jibril during Laylat al-Qadr relates to the implementation and execution of Allah's commands and decrees. This night serves as an annual session where important decisions for the coming year are made and entrusted to angels for implementation. All wise matters are decreed on this night, as mentioned in Surah Ad-Dukhan.

This night functions like an annual administrative session in Allah's cosmic government, where decisions regarding life, death, sustenance, and other significant matters for the upcoming year are finalized and assigned to angels for execution. Under Jibril's leadership, angels spread across the earth to implement these divine commands, and after completing their assignments, they send reports back to Allah about the execution of these decrees.

The final verse declares that this night is complete peace and safety until the break of dawn. This peace encompasses multiple dimensions: prayers are accepted with greater likelihood, worship is rewarded manifold, and the night is filled with divine mercy and blessings that create an atmosphere of spiritual tranquility.

The peace of this night extends from its beginning until dawn breaks, indicating that the entire duration is blessed and sacred. During these hours, the spiritual atmosphere is uniquely conducive to worship, reflection, and seeking divine forgiveness and guidance. The safety mentioned includes protection from evil and harm, as well as the safety that comes from spiritual purification and divine acceptance.

This comprehensive peace and safety make Laylat al-Qadr an ideal time for intensive worship, prayer, seeking forgiveness, and spiritual reflection. The continuation of this blessed state until dawn ensures that believers have ample opportunity to engage in acts of worship and benefit from the extraordinary spiritual rewards and divine mercy available during this sacred time.
